articles.headline: In Yellen Hearing, Senators Push for Fed Changes
articles.snippet: Senators raised few questions about the qualifications of Janet L. Yellen, the nominee for Federal Reserve chairwoman, but criticized the central bank’s policies.
articles.abstract: Senators raised few questions about the qualifications of Janet L. Yellen, the nominee for Federal Reserve chairwoman, but criticized the central bank’s policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The questions that Janet L. Yellen faced on Thursday from senators considering her nomination to lead the Federal Reserve made two things fairly clear: The job is hers, and it’s not going to be easy.

articles.headline: Obama Calls for Patience in Iran Talks
articles.snippet: President Obama argued against a plan to impose new sanctions against Iran while negotiators sought a six-month agreement to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: President Obama argued against a plan to impose new sanctions against Iran while negotiators sought a six-month agreement to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama made a vigorous appeal to Congress on Thursday to give breathing space to his efforts to forge a nuclear deal with Iran, and the prospects for an interim agreement may have improved with the release of a report by international inspectors who said that for the first time in years, they saw evidence that the Iranians have put the brakes on their nuclear expansion.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Health Law Rollout’s Stumbles Draw Parallels to Bush’s Hurricane Response
articles.snippet: President Obama’s problem-plagued rollout of the Affordable Care Act has led to comparisons of the Bush administration’s response to Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s problem-plagued rollout of the Affordable Care Act has led to comparisons of the Bush administration’s response to Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Barack Obama won the presidency by exploiting a political environment that devoured George W. Bush in a second term plagued by sinking credibility, failed legislative battles, fractured world relations and revolts inside his own party.

articles.headline: When a Deal Goes Bad, Blame the Ratings
articles.snippet: A suit by the trustee for two Bear Stearns funds contends that managers relied on ratings by the major credit agencies in purchasing risky securities just before the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: A suit by the trustee for two Bear Stearns funds contends that managers relied on ratings by the major credit agencies in purchasing risky securities just before the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you make an incredibly bad decision during the great credit bubble?

articles.headline: Chief’s Vision for Morgan Stanley Is Showing Some Success
articles.snippet: The bank’s stock is up 59 percent this year, reflecting its growing skill at avoiding the sort of squalls that battered it in recent years.
articles.abstract: The bank’s stock is up 59 percent this year, reflecting its growing skill at avoiding the sort of squalls that battered it in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thunderclouds were gathering in April when James P. Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, went for a run on the beach on Amelia Island in Florida after attending a closed-door meeting of the bank’s top stockbrokers. After just a few miles, the storm began to pick up speed, prompting Mr. Gorman to turn around and head for safety.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Bonds Backed by Solar Power Payments Get Nod
articles.snippet: SolarCity, a leading installer of solar-power systems in the United States, received a low investment-grade rating for the bonds, which will help finance its rapid expansion.
articles.abstract: SolarCity, a leading installer of solar-power systems in the United States, received a low investment-grade rating for the bonds, which will help finance its rapid expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the decades, Wall Street has used many assets to back up the bonds it sells, including car loans, life insurance policies and future royalties on David Bowie’s music. Now, in a milestone of sorts for the emerging solar industry, the finance wizards are embracing a new kind of security, this one backed by solar electricity payments.

articles.headline: U.S. Investigates Currency Trades by Major Banks
articles.snippet: Investigators say groups of traders from several major banks may have influenced currency benchmarks to benefit their employers — actions that may not have been illegal but do highlight lax regulation.
articles.abstract: Investigators say groups of traders from several major banks may have influenced currency benchmarks to benefit their employers — actions that may not have been illegal but do highlight lax regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:56 p.m. | From their desks at some of the world’s biggest banks, traders exchanged a series of instant messages that earned them the nickname “the cartel.”
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Landon Thomas Jr. and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Message From Yellen Is Full Speed Ahead on the Stimulus
articles.snippet: Janet L. Yellen, the president’s nominee to lead the Federal Reserve, made investors confident that the central bank would stick with policies that have sent shares soaring.
articles.abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the president’s nominee to lead the Federal Reserve, made investors confident that the central bank would stick with policies that have sent shares soaring.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Janet L. Yellen speaks, Wall Street listens — and investors liked what they heard on Thursday.

articles.headline: Questions for a New Class of Cholesterol Drugs
articles.snippet: A promising new class of cholesterol-lowering drugs known as PCSK9 inhibitors is being developed.
articles.abstract: A promising new class of cholesterol-lowering drugs known as PCSK9 inhibitors is being developed.
articles.lead_paragraph: New guidelines governing the use of cholesterol-lowering medicines are a huge change for doctors and a vast number of patients, but the impact on the drug industry is expected to be less tumultuous.

articles.headline: China to Ease Longtime Policy of 1-Child Limit
articles.snippet: The Communist Party also said that it would end a much-criticized “re-education through labor” system and institute economic reforms.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party also said that it would end a much-criticized “re-education through labor” system and institute economic reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government will ease its one-child family restrictions and abolish “re-education through labor” camps, significantly curtailing two policies that for decades have defined the state’s power to control citizens’ lives, the Communist Party said Friday.

articles.headline: House Approves Bill That Allows Policy Renewals
articles.snippet: Defying a veto threat, 39 Democrats joined Republicans in approving the measure, which goes further than the fix that President Obama had previously announced.
articles.abstract: Defying a veto threat, 39 Democrats joined Republicans in approving the measure, which goes further than the fix that President Obama had previously announced.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House approved legislation on Friday that would allow insurance companies to renew individual health insurance policies and sell similar ones to new customers next year even if the coverage does not provide all the benefits and consumer protections required by the new health care law.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Robert Pear
